turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Bay-class minehunter.
turn.2: Bay-class minehunter The Bay-class Minehunter Inshores were a class of catamaran-hull mine warfare vessels operating with the Royal Australian Navy from 1986.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Also referred to as the MHCAT (MineHunter CATamaran), the class was an attempt to produce a locally designed inshore mine warfare vessel.
turn.6: Two prototype ships were ordered in 1981, with the first ship, "Rushcutter", commissioned in November 1986.
turn.7: What were some of its challenges?
turn.8: The two ships experienced delays in construction, and the RAN resorted to acquiring six minesweeper auxiliaries (MSA) under the Craft of Opportunity Program to provide an interim mine-warfare capability, while also keeping minesweeper in service until 1990, well beyond her intended decommissioning date.
turn.9: Did they have any other challenges?
turn.10: The ships did not enter service until 1993, due to problems with the sonar.
turn.11: What made it a good candidate for the bay class?
turn.12: One of the identifying features of this class is that vessels have a fibreglass hull constructed with a multi-layer foam sandwich core.
